The date of the GLOF-II project launch shows a long-standing government effort to implement early warning systems, which has failed to gain community trust, emphasizing a persistent policy gap.
The World Bank's 2023 climate data on Pakistan’s temperature rise provides a baseline for understanding the country's accelerating climate change context.
The timeframe of 2019–2022, when Pakistan experienced nearly 90 glacial floods, establishes the scale and frequency of climate-related disasters.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2019 to 2025 illustrates the ongoing and intensifying threat of glacial lake outburst floods in northern Pakistan, especially under climate change conditions.

keyTakeAways: Indigenous knowledge, such as recognizing natural signs like heavy rainfall, animal behavior, and sound patterns, is still being used effectively by local communities to predict and respond to glacial floods.
Despite significant investment in early warning systems (EWS), communities in Gilgit-Baltistan lack trust due to system failures, lack of maintenance, and poor community engagement.

A shepherd named Wasiyat Khan and others saved lives during a glacial lake outburst flood in Skardu Valley by using traditional human-based alert systems, including gunfire signals and observation of environmental cues.
The government’s $37 million GLOF-II project (launched in 2017) failed to establish reliable real-time communication between local sensors and official rescue teams, leading to public skepticism.
Pakistan is among the top 10 most climate-vulnerable countries globally, despite contributing less than 1% of global emissions.
The mean temperature in Pakistan has risen by 1.3°C since the 1950s—twice the global average—increasing glacier melt and flood risks.
Residents report that warnings have historically come from local individuals, not from technological EWS systems, indicating a critical gap in trust and functionality of state-led systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In northern Pakistan, particularly in Gilgit-Baltistan and Ghizer, Indigenous knowledge—such as observing cloud formations, animal behavior, and using sound signals like gunfire—is being relied upon to predict and respond to glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs). Despite significant government spending on early warning systems (EWS), including the $37 million GLOF-II project, communities report widespread distrust due to equipment failures, lack of real-time communication, and poor community engagement. Real-life examples, such as shepherd Wasiyat Khan and Mohammad Hussain, show how traditional human-based warnings successfully saved lives when technological systems failed. The article highlights Pakistan’s status as one of the world’s most climate-vulnerable nations, with rising temperatures and glacier melt increasing flood risks. It calls into question the effectiveness of technology-driven systems without community trust, emphasizing that Indigenous knowledge remains a vital, resilient, and under-recognized tool in climate adaptation.
title: How Indigenous knowledge is aiding Pakistan’s fight against climate change
